case_name: Abdul Sattar Ibrahim Patel v. State

facts.text: Appeal by Abdul Sattar Ibrahim Patel challenging the correctness and validity of the order passed by the High Court of Gujarat convicting him under S. 14 of the Foreigners Act 1946.

anchor.surface_text: by which he challenges the companyrectness and validity of the order passed by the High Court of Gujarat, companyvicting him under S. 14 of the Foreigners Act  XXXI of 1946  and sentencing him to suffer rigorous imprisonment for one year and to pay a fine of rupees one thousand, in default rigorous imprisonment for one year.

facts.text: High Court of Gujarat convicted appellant under S. 14 of the Foreigners Act 1946 and sentenced him to rigorous imprisonment for one year and fine of rupees one thousand, in default rigorous imprisonment for one year.

anchor.surface_text: High Court of Gujarat, companyvicting him under S. 14 of the Foreigners Act  XXXI of 1946  and sentencing him to suffer rigorous imprisonment for one year and to pay a fine of rupees one thousand, in default rigorous imprisonment for one year.

facts.text: Appellant charged before the Judicial Magistrate Ist Class at Godhra with offence under S. 14 of the Foreigners Act.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was charged before the Judicial Magistrate  Ist Class  at Godhra with having companymitted an offence under S. 14 of the Foreigners Act.

facts.text: Appellant obtained Passport No. 351544 from Government of Pakistan on August 11, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: The case against him was that he was a foreigner and a national of Pakistan, and as such had obtained Passport No. 351544 from the Government of Pakistan on August 11, 1955, and had secured a C Visa No. 22144, on October 5, 1957.

facts.text: Appellant secured C Visa No. 22144 on October 5, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: obtained Passport No. 351544 from the Government of Pakistan on August 11, 1955, and had secured a C Visa No. 22144, on October 5, 1957.

facts.text: Appellant entered India on October 13, 1957 with said passport and C Visa.

anchor.surface_text: 1955, and had secured a C Visa No. 22144, on October 5, 1957. It was alleged that with the said passport and C Visa the appellant entered India on October 13, 1957, and obtained residential permit No. 322/57 valid upto December 12, 1957.

facts.text: Appellant obtained residential permit No. 322/57 valid upto December 12, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: the appellant entered India on October 13, 1957, and obtained residential permit No. 322/57 valid upto December 12, 1957. The said permit was extended from time to time until April 12, 1958.

facts.text: Residential permit extended until April 12, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: December 12, 1957. The said permit was extended from time to time until April 12, 1958. Since the appellant did number leave India even though the residential permit issued in his favour had expired,

facts.text: Appellant did not leave India after residential permit expired on April 12, 1958, contravening cl. 7 of Foreigners Order, 1948.

anchor.surface_text: April 12, 1958. Since the appellant did number leave India even though the residential permit issued in his favour had expired, he was alleged to have companytravened the provisions of cl. 7 of the Foreigners Order, 1948, and thereby rendered himself liable to be punished under S. 14 of the Foreigners Act, 1946.

facts.text: Appellant claims he had not gone to Pakistan until August 1954.

anchor.surface_text: In resisting the charge thus framed against him, the appellant urged that he had number gone to Pakistan at all till the month of August, 1954.

facts.text: Appellant's parents were born in Godhra and lived there all the time.

anchor.surface_text: He pleaded that his parents were born in Godhra and they and all his brothers were and are living in Godhra all the time. He claimed the status of an Indian citizen and denied the charge against him that he was a foreigner.

facts.text: Appellant's marriage took place in Godhra and he was educated there preceding marriage.

anchor.surface_text: According to him, his marriage had taken place in Godhra, and preceding his marriage he had also been educated in Godhra. In the month of March, 1948 his father-in-law, Yusuf Haji Ismail went to Pakistan and along with him went his wife.

facts.text: Father-in-law Yusuf Haji Ismail went to Pakistan in March 1948 along with appellant's wife.

anchor.surface_text: In the month of March, 1948 his father-in-law, Yusuf Haji Ismail went to Pakistan and along with him went his wife. In 1954 the appellant had to go to Pakistan to bring back his wife to India,

facts.text: Appellant obtained Indian Passport No. C. 041323 dated April 8, 1954 to travel to Pakistan.

anchor.surface_text: In 1954 the appellant had to go to Pakistan to bring back his wife to India, and in order to travel to Pakistan he made an application for a passport and obtained an Indian Passport No. C. 041323 bearing the date April 8, 1954,

facts.text: Appellant travelled to Karachi with Indian Passport, but passport was taken away or destroyed by father-in-law.

anchor.surface_text: Having travelled to Karachi with the Indian Passport, the appellant wanted to return with his wife to India, but his passport was deliberately taken away or destroyed by his father-in-law with a view to companypel him to stay at Karachi,

facts.text: Learned Magistrate acquitted appellant under S. 251-A (11) of CrPC as prosecution failed to prove charge beyond reasonable doubt.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Magistrate who tried the case was number satisfied that prosecution had proved the charge against the appellant beyond reasonable doubt. ... In the result, the appellant was acquitted under S. 251-A  11  of the Criminal Procedure Code.

facts.text: State of Gujarat appealed against acquittal order.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent, the State of Gujarat, then preferred an appeal against the said order of acquittal.

facts.text: High Court set aside acquittal and convicted appellant under S.14.

anchor.surface_text: But the High Court took the view that the question raised for its decision was of some importance ... the High Court held that the charge had been proved against the appellant and so it set aside the order of acquittal and companyvicted him under S. 14.

facts.text: High Court granted certificate to appeal to Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant then applied for and obtained a certificate from the High Court to companye to this Court, and it is with the said certificate that the present appeal has been brought before us.

arguments.claim: Appellant satisfies Art.5: domiciled in India on 26.1.1950, born in India, parents born in India

anchor.surface_text: Article 5 of the Constitution provides that any person who has his domicile in the territory of India at the commencement of the Constitution and who satisfies one of the three conditions specified by cls. (a), (b) and (c) of the said Article shall be a citizen of India.

arguments.claim: Art.7 excludes citizenship under Art.5 if migrated from India to Pakistan after 1.3.1947; migration requires intent to reside permanently in Pakistan between 1.3.1947 and 26.1.1950

anchor.surface_text: Article 7 with which we are concerned in the present appeal provides that notwithstanding anything contained in Articles 5 and 6, a person who has after the first day of March 1947, migrated from the territory of India to the territory now included in Pakistan shall not be deemed to be a citizen of India.

arguments.claim: Cases after 26.1.1950 fall under Art.9: no citizenship if voluntarily acquired foreign citizenship; decision by Govt of India under Citizenship Act S.9(2) R.3 Sch.III precedent condition

anchor.surface_text: Article 9 provides that no person shall be a citizen of India by virtue of Art. 5, or be deemed, to be a citizen of India by virtue of Ad. 6 or Art. 8 if he has voluntarily acquired the citizenship of any foreign State.

anchor.surface_text: We would accordingly set aside the order of conviction and sentence passed by the High Court against the appellant and remand the case to the Court of the Judicial Magistrate, First Class, at Godhra, with the direction that he should give opportunity to the appellant and the prosecution to lead further evidence on the points at issue

holdings.text: Set aside the order of conviction and sentence passed by the High Court under S.14 Foreigners Act and remand the case to the Judicial Magistrate First Class at Godhra to allow both parties opportunity to lead further evidence on points at issue, consider whole evidence, and make findings.

anchor.surface_text: We would accordingly set aside the order of conviction and sentence passed by the High Court against the appellant and remand the case to the Court of the Judicial Magistrate, First Class, at Godhra, with the direction that he should give opportunity to the appellant and the prosecution to lead further evidence on the points at issue and should consider the whole of the evidence, and then make his findings.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Appellant denied fair opportunity to produce key documentary evidence on Indian passport from official custody due to no fault of his; received records prima facie corroborate 1954 passport application and citizenship recognition by police enquiry; High Court rejected evidence and made incorrect legal observations; requires fresh adjudication for justice.

holdings.text: When question arises whether person prosecuted under Foreigners Act S.14 is a foreigner, S.9 places burden of proof on accused notwithstanding Indian Evidence Act, including to prove domicile in India on 26 January 1950 and satisfaction of Art.5 conditions; trial proceeds on this basis.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant is being prosecuted under S. 14 of the Foreigners Act, 1946 (XXXI of 1946). In determining the question as to whether he is a foreigner within the meaning of the said Act or not, S. 9 of the Act will have to be borne in mind. Section 9 applies to all cases under the Act which do not fall under S. 8, and this case does not fall under S. 8, and so, S. 9 is relevant. Under this section, the legislature has placed the burden of proof on a person who is accused of an offence punishable under S. 14.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct textual application of S.9 Foreigners Act overriding Evidence Act specifically for foreigner status questions in S.14 prosecutions; extends to constitutional citizenship proof under Art.5.

holdings.text: Art.5 confers citizenship on person domiciled in India territory at Constitution commencement who satisfies any one (alternative, not cumulative) of cls.(a) born in India, (b) either parent born in India, or (c) ordinarily resident 5 years preceding; basic condition is domicile on 26 January 1950.

anchor.surface_text: The true legal position in regard to the status of a citizen like the appellant is not in doubt. Article 5 of the Constitution provides that any person who has his domicile in the territory of India at the commencement of the Constitution and who satisfies one of the three conditions specified by cls. (a), (b) and (c) of the said Article shall be a citizen of India. The three conditions are alternative and not cumulative, and so, if any one of those conditions is satisfied, a person would be deemed to be a citizen of India if he had his domicile in the territory of India on January 26, 1950.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Plain textual interpretation of Art.5 structure and conditions.

holdings.text: Art.7 excludes Art.5 citizenship notwithstanding if person migrated from India to Pakistan after 1 March 1947; migration requires leaving between 1 March 1947 and 26 January 1950 with intention of permanent residence in Pakistan; casual temporary leave does not constitute migration.

anchor.surface_text: Article 7 with which we are concerned in the present appeal provides that notwithstanding anything contained in Articles 5 and 6, a person who has after the first day of March 1947, migrated from the territory of India to the territory now included in Pakistan shall not be deemed to be a citizen of India. ... It has been settled by the decisions of this Court that the migration to which Art. 7 refers must have taken place between March 1, 1947 and January 26, 1950 vide State of Madhya Pradesh v. Peer Mahomed.... the requirement of migration postulates that the person must have left India with the intention of residing permanently in Pakistan. Leaving India casually for a specific purpose without intending to settle down permanently in Pakistan would not amount to -migration vide Smt. Shanno Devi v. Mangal Sain.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Precedent binding: temporal limits and intent element from State of MP v. Peer Mohammad and Shanno Devi v. Mangal Sain.

holdings.text: No citizenship under Art.5/6/8 if voluntarily acquired foreign citizenship (Art.9); for such cases post-26.1.1950, Citizenship Act 1955 S.9(2) Sch.III R.3 valid conferring exclusive jurisdiction on Govt of India to determine foreign citizenship acquisition; such decision condition precedent for prosecution treating as foreigner.

anchor.surface_text: Cases in which migration has taken place after January 26, 1950, fall to be considered under Art. 9 of the Constitution. Article 9 provides that no person shall be a citizen of India by virtue of Art. 5, or be deemed, to be a citizen of India by virtue of Ad. 6 or Art. 8 if he has voluntarily acquired the citizenship of any foreign State. ... In Izhar Ahmad Khan v. Union of India... R. 3 of Sch. III, framed under S. 9(2) of the Citizenship Act is valid... jurisdiction to decide... vests exclusively in the Government of India... A decision by the Government of India is a condition precedent... vide Government of Andhra Pradesh v. Mohd. Khan.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Precedent binding: validity and exclusive jurisdiction from Izhar Ahmad Khan v. UOI; condition precedent from Govt of AP v. Mohd. Khan.

holdings.text: High Court observations on true scope and effect of Arts.5,7,9 do not correctly represent legal position.

anchor.surface_text: The Trial Judge was to some extent impressed by the said evidence, but the High Court has rejected that evidence and has made a definite finding that the appellant had failed to establish that an Indian Passport had been issued to him in 1954 or at any time. In dealing with this question the High Court has no doubt made some observations as to the true scope and effect of the provisions contained in Arts. 5, 7 and 9, which do not correctly represent the true legal position in that behalf.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court deviated from correct interpretations stated earlier in judgment on citizenship articles.

precedents.cited_proposition: Migration requires leaving India with the intention of residing permanently in Pakistan; casual departure for specific purpose without intent to settle permanently does not amount to migration

anchor.surface_text: The appellant is being prosecuted under S. 14 of the Foreigners Act, 1946 (XXXI of 1946). In determining the question as to whether he is a foreigner within the meaning of the said Act or not, S. 9 of the Act will have to be borne in mind. Section 9 applies to all cases under the Act which do not fall under S. 8, and this case does not fall under S. 8, and so, S. 9 is relevant. Under this section, the legislature has placed the burden of proof on a person who is accused of an offence punishable under S. 14.

We would accordingly set aside the order of companyviction and sentence passed by the High Court against the appellant and remand the case to the Court of the Judicial Magistrate, First Class, at Godhra, with the direction that he should give opportunity to the appellant and the prosecution to lead further evidence on the points at issue

The true legal position in regard to the status of a citizen like the appellant is not in doubt. Article 5 of the Constitution provides that any person who has his domicile in the territory of India at the commencement of the Constitution and who satisfies one of the three conditions specified by cls. (a), (b) and (c) of the said Article shall be a citizen of India. The three conditions are alternative and not cumulative, and so, if any one of those conditions is satisfied, a person would be deemed to be a citizen of India if he had his domicile in the territory of India on January 26, 1950.

We would accordingly set aside the order of companyviction and sentence passed by the High Court against the appellant and remand the case to the Court of the Judicial Magistrate, First Class, at Godhra, with the direction that he should give opportunity to the appellant and the prosecution to lead further evidence on the points at issue

Article 7 with which we are concerned in the present appeal provides that notwithstanding anything contained in Articles 5 and 6, a person who has after the first day of March 1947, migrated from the territory of India to the territory now included in Pakistan shall not be deemed to be a citizen of India. ... It has been settled by the decisions of this Court that the migration to which Art. 7 refers must have taken place between March 1, 1947 and January 26, 1950 vide State of Madhya Pradesh v. Peer Mahomed.... the requirement of migration postulates that the person must have left India with the intention of residing permanently in Pakistan. Leaving India casually for a specific purpose without intending to settle down permanently in Pakistan would not amount to -migration vide Smt. Shanno Devi v. Mangal Sain.

We would accordingly set aside the order of companyviction and sentence passed by the High Court against the appellant and remand the case to the Court of the Judicial Magistrate, First Class, at Godhra, with the direction that he should give opportunity to the appellant and the prosecution to lead further evidence on the points at issue

anchor.surface_text: Cases in which migration has taken place after January 26, 1950, fall to be considered under Art. 9 of the Constitution. Article 9 provides that no person shall be a citizen of India by virtue of Art. 5, or be deemed, to be a citizen of India by virtue of Ad. 6 or Art. 8 if he has voluntarily acquired the citizenship of any foreign State. ... In Izhar Ahmad Khan v. Union of India... R. 3 of Sch. III, framed under S. 9(2) of the Citizenship Act is valid... jurisdiction to decide... vests exclusively in the Government of India... A decision by the Government of India is a condition precedent... vide Government of Andhra Pradesh v. Mohd. Khan.

We would accordingly set aside the order of companyviction and sentence passed by the High Court against the appellant and remand the case to the Court of the Judicial Magistrate, First Class, at Godhra, with the direction that he should give opportunity to the appellant and the prosecution to lead further evidence on the points at issue
